title: Frontiers in Materials Science
requirements: For students in MSc Physics, MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg or MPhil-PhD Physics
description: Current topics illustrating important research field in materials science will be discussed. Topics covered will include: energy materials, biomaterials, and computational material science. The course provides an introduction to the background concept, physical principles and applications of the relevant material systems.
outcome: Students at the end of the course are expected to have gained an appreciation of the fundamental concepts as well as the state of art methodologies in frontiers of materials research. They are expected to have gained the ability to operationalize these concepts in precise frameworks, and to have the ability to pursue these topics in further depth beyond this course. Some of the material will have to be learnt by the student on their own, and through this activity students will develop the capability and habit of self-directed learning.
syllabus: (1) Energy materials:  (a) Materials for light harvesting and applications: Fundamental concepts of photovoltaics; Principles of solar cell operation and efficiencies; Semiconductor materials for light harvesting and photovoltaic devices; Defects and doping of semiconducting materials for energy applications, including basic concepts of defects in semiconductors and defect engineering (optional); Light harvesting enhancement and plasmonic materials; Material requirement and device configurations of single junction device and tandem cells; Different generations of solar cell devices and their working principles, including crystalline silicon solar cells, thin film solar cells, organic, dye-sensitized cells and hybrid cells  (b) Materials for energy storage and applications: General introduction of battery industry and its advances; Highlight on Li-ion batteries (LiBs): Working principles (e.g., mechanisms of Li-ion intercalation and deintercalation); basic concepts and parameters of LiBs (e.g., capacity, energy density, power density, rate capacity, and cyclability); Common cathode and anode materials and their electrochemical properties; Ionic conductors; Materials Issues and safety aspects in sustainable Li-ion Batteries; State of art batteries beyond conventional LiBs.  (2) Biomaterials: Background concepts on biological systems (e.g., protein, cell, tissue); Classes of materials for medical applications including metals, polymer, hydrogel, ceramics, and biologically functional materials; Properties of biomaterials and characterizations; Interaction between biomaterials and biological systems (e.g., inflammation, and immune response etc.); Toxicology evaluation of the biomaterials; Applications of biomaterials (e.g., drug delivery, tissue engineering)

title: Topics in Advanced Materials Research IV (Electron Microscopy: Principles, Techniques and Analysis)
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg; For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics
description: This course is intended to provide basics of electron microscopy. Topics include: group theory and basics of crystal symmetry; electron diffraction and interpretation of crystal symmetry; wave optics and imaging principle of electron microscopy; high-resolution transmission electron microscopy; analytical electron energy microscopy; and laboratory demonstration of specific topics.
outcome: 1. To master the principle of electron microscopes;2. To know the basic instrumentation of conventional electron microscope, and master the basic sample preparation methods;3. To master the basic knowledge of crystalline symmetry and group theory;4. To understand the theory of electron diffraction;5. To master the methods for the interpretation of crystal symmetry through electron diffraction patterns;6. To understand the principle of dark field/bright field imaging;7. To understand the theory of high-resolution electron microscopy;8. To master data analysis skill of high resolution electron microscopy images;9. To understanding energy dispersive x-ray, and master data analysis skills in identifying material composition;10. To understand electron energy loss spectroscopy method in identifying material chemical composition and electronic structures;11. To understand the state-of-the-art in situ techniques in monitoring dynamics of material structural/ compositional/ property changes;12. To analyze, judge and solve realistic problems and cases using combinational approaches (including diffraction pattern, dark field/bright field images, high resolution image, EDX, EELS, etc.);13. To develop an analytical mind towards materials characterization;14. To master basic experimental skills in using electron microscopy based techniques for practical material analysis projects.
syllabus: Principles of electron scattering and basics of electron microscopyGroup theory and basics of crystal symmetry;Electron diffraction and crystal symmetry interpretation from the reciprocal space; Comparison with x-ray diffraction;Wave optics and imaging principle of electron microscopy;Theory and interpretation of high-resolution electron microscopy;Analytical electron energy microscopy techniques including energy dispersive x-ray (EDX), electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), and various state-of-the-art in situ microscopy techniques.
recommended_readings: 1. “Transmission Electron microscopy”, D. B. Williams and C. B. Carter, Plenum Press, New York and London2. “Electron Microscopy of Thin Crystals” By P. Hirsch et al., Krieger Publishing Company, Malabar, Florida3. “Transmission Electron Microscopy—Physics of image formation and microanalysis” L. Reimer, Springer-Verlag

title: Surface Science
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg; For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics
description: This course serves as an introduction to surface science. Major topics are: vacuum technology, electron-surface interactions, photon-surface interactions, ion-surface interactions, scanning probe microscopy and case studies in surface science.
